title: 35 years of product design wisdom from Apple, Disney, Pinterest and beyond | Bob Baxley
themes: Netflix product decisions and case studies
key_insights: Product strategy should delight customers in hard-to-copy, margin-enhancing ways - balancing customer value with business sustainability
The JAM framework (Joy, Attachment, Monetization) helps align leadership on prioritization across growth, engagement, and revenue
Avoid 'two-percenters' - features that only 2% of customers use create complexity without meaningful impact
Test the 'perfect experience' first to understand true customer value before optimizing costs
Build a personal board of directors by helping others first, then leveraging relationships for career guidance
Career advancement requires treating your path like product development - hypothesis, experiment, iterate
High-stakes vs low-stakes decision framework: consider magnitude and reversibility before over-analyzing
Start with a SWAG (Stupid Wild-Ass Guess) rather than spending months perfecting strategy in isolation

guest_background.current_role: Independent product strategy teacher and consultant

topics_discussed: JAM prioritization model: Joy, Attachment, Monetization
Netflix case studies: Perfect New Release test, Netflix Party decision, auto-cancellation strategy
Product manager career progression to CPO level
Daily habits and routines for product managers
Building personal advisory networks and mentorship
Balancing customer delight with business metrics
Social features and network effects in streaming
memorable_quotes: The job of an entrepreneur at the beginning is just to find out something that's 10X better. Delight is trying to work in that magnitude.
Don't listen to your parents, because they're a generation ahead. They really don't know what the future looks like.
At some point, understand that you are responsible for your career, not your workplace.
recommended_for: Anyone interested in Netflix's product development
summary: Gibson Biddle shares battle-tested frameworks from his time at Netflix and other companies, focusing on his DHM product strategy model and JAM prioritization framework. The conversation blends tactical product management advice with career development insights, using real Netflix case studies to illustrate decision-making principles.
